properties.areaDesc: Sacramento Mountains Above 7500 Feet; East Slopes Sacramento Mountains Below 7500 Feet
properties.senderName: NWS El Paso TX/Santa Teresa NM
properties.headline: Winter Storm Warning issued February 4 at 7:17PM MST until February 5 at 8:00AM MST by NWS El Paso TX/Santa Teresa NM
properties.description:
...WINTER STORM TO IMPACT THE SACRAMENTO MOUNTAINS, THE EASTERN
LOWLANDS OF OTERO COUNTY, AND HUDSPETH COUNTY...

.Cold front moving through the area with drop temperatures rapidly
and change any precipitation to snow overnight. Some moderate to
heavy snow is currently falling over the Sacramento Mountains and
should continue into Wednesday morning. The east slopes and
central portion of the mountains are expected to receive the
heaviest snowfall as low level east flow increases throughout
tonight. Snow accumulation is expected across Hudspeth County and
the lowlands of Otero County. The snow should taper off and end
by around noon on Wednesday.

* WHAT...Heavy snow. Up to 6 inches of snow has already fallen
this morning, and additional snow accumulations of 2 to 4
inches are expected.

* SNOW AMOUNTS...Total snow accumulations 4 to 8 inches likely,
with up to 10 inches over higher elevations.

* WHERE...East slopes and central portion of Sacramento Mtns.

* WHEN...Until 8 AM MST Wednesday.

* TIMING...Occasional moderate to heavy snow this afternoon;
more frequent heavy snow overnight. Snow tapering off and
ending by noon time Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Some roads could
become impassable and/or closed. The cold wind chills as low
as zero to 5 below zero could result in hypothermia if
precautions are not taken.
properties.instruction:
If you must travel, keep an extra flashlight, food, and water in
your vehicle in case of an emergency.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

NWSheadline: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 AM MST WEDNESDAY
